message.content: This question requires an understanding of how the position of the sun affects the size of a person's shadow. The smallest shadow occurs when the sun is directly overhead, which is at its highest point in the sky. This usually happens around noon, so option (C), 12:30 pm, is the correct answer. Options (A), (B), and (D) all represent times when the sun is not directly overhead, so the shadows would be longer.

To answer this question, we need to consider the position of the sun in the sky throughout the day. The size of a person's shadow is determined by the angle at which the sunlight hits the person and the length of the person's body.

At 8:00 am and 6:30 pm, the sun is at a lower angle in the sky, which means the shadows will be longer. Therefore, options (B) and (D) can be eliminated.

At 4:00 pm, the sun is starting to descend, so the shadows will be longer compared to noon. Therefore, option (A) can be eliminated.

At 12:30 pm, the sun is at its highest point in the sky (assuming a standard time zone). This means that the sunlight is coming from directly above, causing objects to have very short or almost non-existent shadows. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer.

In summary, a person's shadow is smallest at 12:30 pm because the sun is directly overhead, creating minimal shadows.
